item.title: Cinema 88, first part
item.itunes:author: thenew
item.description: Films from 1988, first part: the obvious ones and the early surprises
item.itunes:summary: Films from 1988, first part: the obvious ones and the early surprises
item.itunes:subtitle: Films from 1988, first part: the obvious ones and the early surprises
item.content:encoded:
French audio version, music: Kaneda (from "AKIRA Symphonic Suite") by Geinoh Yamashirogumi

1988 was the year of the first steps of the World Wide Web, the World Expo in Brisbane, the unique time the male football team of The Netherlands has been champion and, closer to me, French president Fran√ßois Mitterrand was reelected.
But more importantely I also came to this world.
So, for no more reason, I decided a few months ago to watch as many films from 88 as possible.

Let‚Äôs start with the films I already saw:

The Obvious Ones

Die Hard

by John McTiernan - Disney+




Bruce Willis was the action hero of my childhood with The Fifth Element. He was like Son Goku: he saves the day without coming out unscathed.
I saw the film a long time ago and thought I remembered it well but after watching it again, I only had in mind the more than iconic moments, and they are plenty: the fire hose, the ventilation ducts, the duct tape in the back, Hans‚Äô fall, etc.

But the film is so generous, it‚Äôs a non-stop ride. The intricate villain‚Äôs plan is slowly unfolding while actions sequences go on. John McClain is smart but not smarter than the bad guys. The German gymnasts are hilarious, Alan Rickman's performance is insane.
The cinematography of Jan de Bont starts in warm Los Angeles sunshine before quickly dives into dark night and high lights.
The directing of McTiernan is only at its best in motion.
I totally forgot that the Christmas music is used all along the movie, it‚Äôs fun and revelling.
The exposition is smart: the first dialogue in the plane introduces the protagonist and is the cause of him being bare feet during the rest of his suffering. The touchscreen at the entrance of the building is a proof of its high technology but also shows to John that his wife changed name. Examples are numerous.

I‚Äôm sure that, as a kid, I also loved the mocking tone. The film is sparing no one: the greedy journalists, the frat boys FBI agents Johnson and Johnson (haha), the imbecile chief of police, the businessman full of coke.

Akira

„Äå„Ç¢„Ç≠„É©„Äç by Katsuhiro Otomo

It‚Äôs still one of the best animated films of all time. I love other works from Otomo in animation or manga. It's a cornerstone of the animation history and a huge influence in cyberpunk aesthetic. We should watch and rewatch it, no doubt.

My Neighbor Totoro

„Äå„Å®„Å™„Çä„ÅÆ„Éà„Éà„É≠„Äç by Hayao Miyazaki and Studio Ghibli

The career of Hayao Miyazaki doesn‚Äôt contain any mistakes, in my opinion, and the character of Totoro is more than iconic so, obviously, I recommend you to see it. It‚Äôs, first of all a film for children and I would have loved to see it earlier, maybe that‚Äôs why Totoro is not in my favourites Miyazaki.

Grave of the Fireflies

„ÄåÁÅ´ÂûÇ„Çã„ÅÆÂ¢ì„Äç by Isao Takahata and Studio Ghibli

It was not a bad year for animation, clearly. I understand the praise for Grave of the Fireflies and it was for a long time in my watch list but it‚Äôs a bit too much tearjerker for my taste. Anecdote: I watched it for the first time in 2018, in a cinema, during a strange screening with technical difficulties and a neighbour eating tacos, so appropriate.

And The First Surprises

They Live

by John Carpenter




So badass and stupid at the same time, it has a real punk feeling. I love Carpenter and am slowly catching up on his films. I was surprised by the groom beginning, I was expecting a more fun satire. They Live is a great melting pot of political critic, cartoonish scenes and a pulp story.

Working Girl

by Mike Nichols - Disney+




I only knew Mike Nichols for The Graduate so I was prepared for some darkness but it‚Äôs well hidden behind a joyful romantic comedy.
Harisson Ford and Sigourney Weaver are having a ball and Kevin Spacey plays an asshole, as always. Melanie Griffith is even more annoying than in Body Double but we could say its na√Øvet√© helps the story.
The boss, Katharine, is smartly portrayed: she knows the tricks, even if younger, to stay at this position of power.
The last scene shows how ecstatic Tess is by her new position, but then the camera slowly backtracks, revealing a different view: she is just another small gear in the machine.
This last shot leaving the city also reflects the nice first shot.

Police Story

„ÄäË≠¶ÂØüÊïÖ‰∫ã„Äã with Jackie Chan

Released in 1985 in Hong Kong, but in 1987 in France and 1988 in USA.

Wow! I love Jacky Chan and I was a big fan as a kid but I wasn‚Äôt aware of this saga until late. I finally catch up and, clearly, I‚Äôm not used (yet) to the HK cinema. It‚Äôs almost just a suite of stunt scenes but the other scenes are surprisingly telling a coherent story. It‚Äôs simple and goofy but you can feel the rage. The sequel has been originally released in 1988 so I‚Äôm looking forward to include it in my next list.

Tucker, the man and his dream

by Francis Ford Coppola - Netflix

First time watching a Coppola film after Apocalypse Now. I didn't expect this over-the-top, joyful, car ride. I liked the too-big-for-life character. Always smiling but also too aggressive with his team.

The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad!

by David Zucker

Not the best from the series but still love it, way too salacious.
Some lines are still great ("A parachute not opening‚Ä¶that's a way to die." :D)

The Bear

L‚ÄôOurs by Jean Jacques Annaud

Except some trippy nightmare scenes that don‚Äôt fit with the rest of the film, I enjoyed a lot the cinematography and the journey. The animals are very beautifully filmed. The story is more engaging than I expected. Peculiar shots (close-ups, first person, distorted) are cleverly flavouring the direction.

Dead Ringers

by David Cronenberg


So weird. Adapted from a true story, which makes it even weirder. It‚Äôs touching many topics, from science, gynaecology, fecundity, drugs, identity, links. It's convincing, good performance from Irons but I don‚Äôt grasp the story.
Nice decorum, this late 80s black marble and red surgeon tunics are amazing.
Seeing again a lonely crazy Iron eating birthday cake after the Watchmen TV show was a pleasure.
Pretty subtle for a Cronenberg after all.

Mississippi Burning

by Alan Parker

Some nice dynamic shots. Reminds me of Spielberg. Lots of extras. Army of feds.
Frances McDormand plays a brave, cute and smart character. Gene Hackman is a player, real fun, playing dumber than he is.
Willem Dafoe is so young, he looks almost trustable.
Too bad, the black character with the most lines is a buccaneer from the cop but it‚Äôs a really good scene.
The film takes the time to show that the lawless actions at the end are understandable.
The interviews of the locals are chilling and all the KKK‚Äôs arguments are still in the air today. It‚Äôs revolting.

Red Heat

by Walter Hill




An average 80s buddy movie despite Arnold Schwarzenegger. Almost nothing memorable but some good supporting actors. Laurence Fishburne has a minor role but Gina Gershon is stunning, as always.
It begins with a fight in a hammam and finishes with a bus chase, it could sound hot but it‚Äôs not.
The duo Schwarzy forms with Jim Belushi reminded me the one he has with Tom Arnold in True Lies but Red Heat pales in comparison with James Cameron‚Äôs piece of art.

The Big Blue

Le Grand Bleu by Luc Besson




I like the pace of the movie, even with this length and the narrow main topic.
Jean Reno playing in the Mediterranean reminds me so much Porco Rosso (he did the French dub and I love it), therefore I‚Äôm not objective.
Weird love scene, some stereotypical scenes (thanks Luc!) and wide shots are overused.
The theme can be annoying but the rest of the soundtrack is good, but it's super funky cheesy.

The Little Thief

La Petite Voleuse by Claude Miller

I don't have the context and it‚Äôs not my cinema so I'm not comfortable criticising it. But I felt uncomfortable, to say the least, seeing a 16- or 17-year-old Charlotte Gainsbourg‚Äôs character sex stories.

Who Framed Roger Rabbit

by Robert Zemeckis - Disney+

I love Zemeckis‚Äô works but I avoided this film for a long time because I simply can't stand the Toons: Roger rabbit, Donald duck, Tom & Jerry, etc. they all cringe my gears.
So the movie is a real tour de force and withstands the test of time incredibly well but I'm not a fan of the universe so it was a bit painful to watch.
I will remember the introduction, it‚Äôs a scene for the in-universe cartoon so it's 2D animation but some shots are so dynamic I'm wondering if they used 3D modelling. The fact that I can't see if it's 2D or 3D alone is pretty rare but from a 1988 movie, it‚Äôs impressive.

That‚Äôs all for now,
my watch list of 1988 films is already long and I‚Äôm excited to see some of them but I‚Äôll try to diversify more the genres and explore my discomfort zone.
Feel free to recommend me your favourites ones.

See you next time.

Fin

item.title: RadioKawa Retrospective postmortem
item.itunes:author: thenew
item.content:encoded:
version audio, music: Sappy by Neil D. Voss

To honour the end of the French-speaking podcast network RadioKawa, with whom I have worked since 2015, I designed and developed this retrospective website: https://retrospective.radiokawa.com/.

I gathered the timeline, inspirations and some thoughts for a postmortem.

While I was working on complex websites, doing more backend than frontend in my day-to-day work, I was searching to do more web animations and reconnect a bit with GSAP.
RadioKawa has tons of content (shows, authors, categories, episodes, etc.) I‚Äôm aware of and is a non-profit organisation, so it was a good client to animate some big numbers on my free time.

Timeline

I started noodling the design around 9 February 2020 and then send a message to the RadioKawa team to share my idea and a first mock-up on the 24th. I was glad to receive positive feedback.
In March, Yann, the Big Boss, helped me gather appropriate data and collect photographs. On the next three months, during a particularly enjoyable time called lockdown, I streamed, for the first time, some coding sessions.

I continued working on it in the evenings and weekends, slowly but surely. Adding a few, simpler, blocks in the last days. The page was finally launched on the 3rd of July.

Design

My first wish in this project was to play around with Figma and I got more accustomed with it. I‚Äôm still missing some features from Illustrator but it‚Äôs an amazing tool and web-based, so you can share it in a blink of an eye. You can try my font plugin, by the way ;).

Not being a designer, I want to stress it, my biggest mistake was to not choose a correct format/ratio to work on, way too much high, it did not correspond to any realistic devices viewports. So the transition to development was a bit tricky.

Then, while finishing the development, I realised I totally ignored mobile version, which is pretty foolish. I thought it would be complicated to redesign this big blocks in a small viewport, but it was less a conundrum than expected. It made me test the Figma Mirror mobile app, which is awesome to live preview on your device, it‚Äôs literally just log in and play.

Development

I started to code my own scroll animation manager but ScrollTrigger was announced and released just at the beginning of the development so I quickly drop my draft to try the new toy from Greensock.
It‚Äôs well done and kills ScrollMagic, IMHO. The debug tools are nice, but I‚Äôm not sure if I‚Äôll ever get used to the syntax. As an efficient but limited framework, it was perfect for this kind of project.

I wanted to try replicate this wrapped typography animation with just CSS and JS. I know they are made with WebGL but when you see how complex it is, I wanted to play dumb. So I‚Äôm surprised it kinda works visually but the performances are terrible, will not recommend.
This was my swan song of dumb HTML animations before jumping on the GL train, maybe.

In the same idea of ‚Äã‚Äãplaying low-key, I didn‚Äôt want to code any lazy loading for the assets so I tried the HTML version: if you want a quick lazy loading, the loading img attribute (mdn, web.dev) is a nice native feature, you don‚Äôt have control on the loading of the images but it‚Äôs plug-and-play.
Just one thing to consider: if the image is on position: fixed the browser will load it immediately so you should change the image styles with JavaScript after the document load: put the position to fixed or remove a display: none, for example.

I had to abandon some designs by lack of time, I‚Äôm still glum about it.

Finally, thanks to Valockar for putting it on a new subdomain for more premium feeling ‚ú®

Refs

The Spotify annual reports were the main inspiration, they are sadly almost impossible to browse again but we have some case studies:

  • Spotify Wrapped 2018 and Active Theory‚Äôs great case study

  • An analysis of Spotify Wrapped 2019

  • I love Area17 design and its 2019 report was an inspiration, especially the first hero block, obviously: https://2019.area17.com/

  • Cineville, a Dutch cinema subscription, did a good job with its year report: https://filmblik.cineville.nl/

  • Or random Corn Flakes box cover ¬Ø_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

item.title: Videogames at V&A
item.itunes:author: thenew
item.description: Visite √† l'exposition Videogames Design/Play/Disrupt au mus√©e Victoria & Albert √† Londres.
item.itunes:summary: Visite √† l'exposition Videogames Design/Play/Disrupt au mus√©e Victoria & Albert √† Londres.
item.itunes:subtitle: Visite √† l'exposition Videogames Design/Play/Disrupt au mus√©e Victoria & Albert √† Londres.
item.content:encoded:
version audio

Quelle sera la nation qui ouvrira le premier grand mus√©e du jeu vid√©o ?

En attendant, la Grande-Bretagne est plut√¥t active : Videogames: Design/Play/Disrupt est la derni√®re d‚Äôune courte liste d‚Äôexpositions majeures sur le jeu.

Videogames √©tait organis√©e du 8 septembre 2018 au 24 f√©vrier 2019 dans le magnifique et immense mus√©e Victoria & Albert.
Le V&A a √©t√© fond√© en 1852 en tant que Mus√©e des manufactures apr√®s l‚ÄôExposition universelle de 1851, sp√©cialis√© dans l‚Äôart et le design, il √©tait le lieu parfait pour monter ce projet.
L‚Äôexposition va d‚Äôailleurs continuer son existence dans l‚Äôantenne √©cossaise du V&A.

L‚Äôexposition s‚Äôouvrait sur une citation de Frank Lantz :

‚ÄúMaking games combines everything that‚Äôs hard about building a bridge with everything that‚Äôs hard about composing an opera. Games are basically operas made out of bridges.‚Äù

Le but du projet √©tait donc bien de pr√©senter les structures qui soutiennent la cr√©ation d‚Äôun jeu vid√©o √† un public plut√¥t n√©ophyte.

Design

La premi√®re partie consistait √† mettre √† nu la conception d‚Äôun jeu, √† travers plusieurs ≈ìuvres :

  • L‚Äô√©criture d‚Äôune histoire avec Journey
  • La cr√©ation visuelle de l‚Äôunivers de Last of Us
  • Comment la forme peut na√Ætre de la fonction, le game design au c≈ìur de la cr√©ation, comme pour Splatoon
  • L‚Äô√©criture, plus litt√©raire (dialogues, embranchements) avec Kentucky Route Zero
  • La r√©flexion artistique sur le m√©dium de Tale of Tales

Amusant de noter la multitude de carnets de notes utilis√©s par les concepteurs. Peut-√™tre le seul outil universel.

Un √©cran g√©ant affichait ensuite le grandiose du jeu vid√©o √† travers les affrontements en esport ou dans les MMO avec des extraits de League of Legends et EVE Online.

Disrupt

La section suivante servait de rappel n√©cessaire que la politique dans le jeu vid√©o, ce n‚Äôest pas sale.
La sc√©nographie, tr√®s soign√©e, pr√©sentait les diff√©rents sujets avec des intercalaires color√©s sur des tables r√©tro√©clair√©es, dans une ambiance studieuse.
Pour r√©sumer grossi√®rement le propos : l‚Äôindustrie est toujours tr√®s centr√©e sur la culture occidentale dominante.

Play

L‚Äôexposition ne manquait pas de proposer des interactions √† chaque √©tape du parcours, mais le playground final permet de se concentrer sur le fun, l‚Äôexp√©rimentation des appareils physiques et le multi joueur avec des jeux con√ßus pour des festivals, donc parfaits pour √™tre manipul√©s par un grand nombre.

Derni√®re √©tape obligatoire, la boutique, semble bien petite et laiss√©e pour compte, l‚Äôunivers de Splatoon est tellement con√ßu autour de la surconsommation que je m‚Äôattendais √† √™tre submerg√© de goodies.

La s√©lection de jeux √©tait une tr√®s bonne surprise : √©clectique et pertinente. Comme Journey, premier titre expos√©, qui est une ≈ìuvre esth√©tiquement magnifique et facile √† aborder mais qui renferme plus de complexit√©, comme le r√©v√©lait le prototype des m√©caniques multijoueurs.
Cette exposition √©tait un plaisir √† explorer, les nombreux aspects du m√©dium √©taient enchain√©s avec fluidit√©. M√™me si elle m√©ritait un plus grand espace, nous nous sentions un peu √† l‚Äô√©troit.

Plus de photos et vid√©os

Fin

item.title: 2018 Awards
item.itunes:author: thenew
item.description: Bilan artistique subjectif de l'ann√©e 2018, les meilleures s√©ries TV, jeux vid√©o, films, podcasts, chansons mais aussi mes bandes-annonces ou projets web pr√©f√©r√©s de l'ann√©e.
item.itunes:summary: Bilan artistique subjectif de l'ann√©e 2018, les meilleures s√©ries TV, jeux vid√©o, films, podcasts, chansons mais aussi mes bandes-annonces ou projets web pr√©f√©r√©s de l'ann√©e.
item.itunes:subtitle: Bilan artistique subjectif de l'ann√©e 2018, les meilleures s√©ries TV, jeux vid√©o, films, podcasts, chansons mais aussi mes bandes-annonces ou projets web pr√©f√©r√©s de l'ann√©e.
item.content:encoded:
version audio

Avant de commencer 2019, je fais mon bilan personnel de l‚Äòann√©e pass√©e dans divers domaines artistiques. Vu le nombre de tr√®s bonnes s√©ries TV, le calendrier de sorties JV, etc, inutile de pr√©ciser que cette liste est partiale.
L‚Äòann√©e 2018 √©tait ultra-violette, ma couleur pr√©f√©r√©e, voyons si j‚Äôai √©t√© g√¢t√© dans mes tops.

Cinema

üèÜ Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse
Je suis sorti la george serr√©e de la s√©ance, submerg√© par l‚Äô√©motion subtilement √©grain√©e par le film mais surtout par la puissance visuelle maintenue tout au long de ces 2 heures et par l‚Äôhommage √† des d√©cennies de comics.

Mentions

  • A Quiet place
    Enfin un bon film de genre high-concept. Une exp√©rience inhabituelle en cin√©ma.
  • Annihilation
    Encore une exp√©rience marquante de l‚Äôann√©e, la sc√®ne de fin avec l'inconnu m‚Äôa glac√© comme rarement.
  • Roma
  • Lawrence of Arabia et 2001: A Space Odyssey en 70mm √† EYE Film (Amsterdam), c‚Äòest grandiose.

Mon top sur SensCritique

Film trailer

üèÜ POK√âMON Detective Pikachu
Bon, √ßa pourrait √™tre pour la blague mais la bande-annonce est sinc√®rement bizarre et, surtout, sortie de (presque) nulle part.

Mentions

  • VICE
    Je d√©teste The Big Short, mais Bush jou√© par Sam Rockwell et Dick Cheney par Christian Bale fonctionnent tellement bien, en tout cas, dans la B-A.

  • Avengers End Game
    ‚ÄúPart of the journey is the end‚Äù

TV


üèÜ Vermin
Diffus√©e sur Blackpills, cette s√©rie devrait √™tre plus connue. Direction artistique impeccable et doublage hilarant, mention sp√©ciale au personnage du commissaire par Ga√´l Mectoob.

Mentions

  • Wild Wild Country
    Pas fan des ‚Äúhistoires vraies‚Äù mais cette s√©rie documentaire est fictionnelle, ce n‚Äôest pas possible autrement !
  • Maniac
  • Homecoming
  • The good place
    Il me tarde de regarder la saison 3 de ma s√©rie SF actuelle pr√©f√©r√©e
  • Final Space
    L'humour lourdingue du perso principal g√¢che un peu la f√™te mais √ßa fait super plaisir de voir une s√©rie d'animation Space opera, vous en connaissez d‚Äôautres vous ?
  • Leftovers
    J'ai un an de retard pour la derni√®re saison, mais cette s√©rie est exceptionnelle. La musique, seule, me fout les frissons.

Mon top sur SensCritique

Music video


üèÜ Dolly.Zero - Antoine Debarge - Ugo Bienvenu
Coup de c≈ìur d√©couvert au KLIK Amsterdam Animation Festival, je vais suivre Ugo Bienvenu avec grand attention.

Mentions

  • This is america - Childish Gambino - Hiro Murai
    Notes: la performance live au SNL m'a fait d√©couvrir cette technique folle de Future Weapons qui synchronise les lasers avec le framerate de la cam√©ra.
  • Free Yourself - The Chemical Brothers
  • POP/STARS - K/DA - Fortiche Prod
    La chanson est oubliable, bien que catchy, mais la r√©alisation par le studio parisien FORTICHE est de tr√®s haut niveau. Eh oui, League of Legends cr√©e des pop stars.
  • Mr. FEAR - SIAM√âS
  • My Way - BVG
  • Les passantes - Georges Brassens - Charlotte Abramow

Music live

üèÜ The Chemicals Brothers
Un show plein de surprises et de bons titres, les mecs sont bons, forc√©ment, √ßa aide.

Mentions

  • Silent Alarm - Bloc Party
  • datamatics [ver.2.0] - Ryoji Ikeda
  • Alt-J
    Vu au Bostheater, un th√©atre en plein air, au milieu de la foret d‚ÄôAmsterdam, je recommande le lieu et le groupe.

Music

Difficile de faire un top quand j‚Äôai majoritairement √©cout√© d‚Äôanciennes chansons dont mes deux chouchous : la d√©couverte d‚ÄôOperator Please (Gloves, Yes Yes Vindictive) et Lastman (Original Series Soundtrack) par Avril & Monthaye

Mentions

  • Francis Trouble - Albert Hammond Jr.
    Je me suis senti tellement honteux par le manque d‚Äôengouement du public les deux fois o√π il a jou√© √† Amsterdam cette ann√©e. Encore meilleur que ces pr√©c√©dents albums.
  • Marble Skies et Winter‚Äôs Beach - Django Django
    Aussi vu deux fois en live cette ann√©e, d√©cidement, dont une fois au Razzmatazz √† Barcelone. Imaginez le rideau qui tombe sur la sc√®ne d‚Äôun club √† 1¬†h du mat alors que le DJ jou√© 10 secondes plus t√¥t, c‚Äô√©tait surr√©aliste.
  • Lavender by Half Waif
  • First Man (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack) - Justin Hurwitz

Mon profil Last.fm

Video game trailer

üèÜ Cyberpunk 2077 (E3)
Meilleure bagnole de l‚Äôann√©e. Bonne bande-son, parti pris original de l‚Äôunivers cyberpunk. Et cette voiture, mon dieu !

Mentions

  • Sable (E3)
    Magnifique avec la musique de Japanese Breakfast
  • Beyond Good & Evil 2 (E3)
  • The Last of Us Part II (E3)
    Les animations faciales sont g√™nantes et la s√©quence de gameplay est conformiste mais le reste est tr√®s touchant. La musique de Crooked Still est superbement utilis√©e.
  • Tous Death Stranding

Video games

üèÜ Super Smash Bros. Ultimate
Un poil par d√©faut, c‚Äôest le jeu le plus carr√© qui remporte la coupe. Un syst√®me qui a fait ses preuves mais avec encore plus de contenu, mais vraiment beaucoup plus, il en devient incomparable √† d‚Äôautres jeux de combat.

Mentions

  • Dead Cells
    Ma relation amour/haine avec les roguelites m‚Äô√©tonne toujours.
  • Subnautica
    que je d√©couvre en ce moment donc j'esp√®re encore √™tre surpris.

Mon top sur SensCritique

Titles


üèÜ Pilote Dragon ending - Le temps de la rentr√©e: Koi no Ieji (Shingakki)
La s√©rie est √©trangement amusante m√™me si j‚Äôaurai du mal √† la recommander. Mais il suffit de me passer du France Gall sauce japonaise en g√©n√©rique de fin et j‚Äôai envie de twister.

Mentions

  • Isle of Dogs

Sinon une belle s√©lection sur Art of the Title : Top 10 Title Sequences of 2018

Podcast

üèÜ Le Cosy Corner
Toujours de tr√®s haute qualit√©, les podcasts de M√©doc et Moguri sont int√©ressants, amusants et constamment surprenants alors que le format n‚Äôa presque pas chang√©. C‚Äôest le seul podcast que je sacralise un peu, j‚Äôattends toujours le meilleur moment pour me l‚Äô√©couter.

Mentions

Tellement de bons podcasts √† mentionner, mais peu de nouveaut√©s cette ann√©e dans ma liste d‚Äôabonnements et toujours aucun en langue anglaise :

  • Les D√©mons du MIDI
  • TVNR
  • Torr√©faction
  • Les Clairvoyants
  • Batoru
  • Les Croissants, si on peut parler de podcast ^^
  • Affaires Sensibles
  • LOL Japon
  • Super Cin√© Battle
  • Capture mag
  • Le GrohlCast
  • Morceaux Choisis
  • Calvinball
  • 2 heures de perdues

Brand identity

Comme l‚Äôann√©e derni√®re avec la F1, le sport est toujours tr√®s porteur de jolis projets.

üèÜ France.tv - Joosnabhan et Movement
D‚Äôautres infos sur lenodal

Mentions

  • Fox Sports Netherlands
  • USL - Athletics
  • FA Women‚Äôs leagues - Nomad
  • 2018 AICP Awards title - The Mill
